title: 107_hr1181
content: The Act titled "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" introduces a new section, 25B, in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces section 25B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage paid by individuals for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is subject to limitations based on monthly coverage amounts. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage paid by individuals, subject to limitations based on monthly coverage amounts. The monthly limitation for an individual is $1,500 divided by 12. Up to 2 individuals can be considered for the tax credit. Married individuals have a special rule. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage under the Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 has a special rule for married individuals who do not file a joint return and do not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year. Only the individual meeting these criteria may be considered for the tax credit. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage has a special rule for married individuals who do not file a joint return and do not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year. An eligible coverage month is defined as a month where the individual is covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer, and there was a 12-month period before that month where the individual had continuous coverage. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage has a special rule for married individuals who do not file a joint return and do not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year. The credit is reduced based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with a special rule for married individuals who do not file a joint return and do not live apart from their spouse. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, which includes any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. Rounding rules apply to determine the credit amount. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, with rounding rules applied to determine the credit amount. The applicable dollar amount varies depending on the number of individuals covered by the insurance. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, with rounding rules applied to determine the credit amount. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance that constitutes medical care, excluding insurance with coverage mainly of excepted benefits. The term "qualified health insurance" excludes coverage with less than 50% cost borne by the taxpayer and does not include insurance if substantially all coverage is of excepted benefits. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under certain government-provided programs like title XVIII, XIX, or XXI of the Social Security Act. The term "qualified health insurance" excludes coverage with less than 50% cost borne by the taxpayer and does not include insurance if substantially all coverage is of excepted benefits. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under certain government-provided programs like title XVIII, XIX, or XXI of the Social Security Act, chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code, chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Coverage under these programs is considered coverage under qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. Special rules apply to the tax credit for qualified health insurance. No credit is allowed if the amount paid for insurance is used for other deductions. The credit is also denied to dependents if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. In the case of a taxable year beginning after 2002, dollar amounts in subsections (b)(2)(A) and (c)(3) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3). The dollar amount for a taxable year is adjusted by the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100, it will be rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100. The dollar amount for a taxable year is adjusted by the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year and rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the tax code. Sec. 25B addresses health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals. The effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 2001. Section 3 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs for employees and self-employed individuals under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules include not counting this amount towards other deductions and not allowing the deduction for self-employment tax purposes. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is not allowed for self-employment tax purposes. Section 62 of the tax code has been amended to include this deduction. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is allowed by section 222 of the tax code. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 is amended to reflect this change. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs under section 222 of the tax code applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
